fields.headline: The journalism student
fields.bodyText: I've always had an interest in writing and the news, and the North West Institute's newspaper journalism course just seemed right for me. The institute is close to home and it has a good reputation. The tutors are all experienced writers who have been in the industry, so that helps a lot. We're looking at the different types of newspapers, and we've done shorthand, intros to stories and how to write articles. We're also learning about the laws of journalism: what you can write and what you can't. We haven't done any editing or proofreading yet, but I've only been on the course for a month. Learning the shorthand is getting easier - it's completely new to me and I'm finding it a wee bit more difficult than I expected. At the moment, I can do about 60wpm. I'm really enjoying writing articles. I love writing. I always loved English at school, and started writing stories and stuff at primary school. I'm doing a work placement for one day a week from November for the rest of the year. I haven't organised it yet, but I'm hoping to work on a newspaper close to home and get to see the day-to-day running and how things work. I'm really looking forward to it; it's what attracted me to the course. There are loads of good facilities at the college: there's a newsroom with computers and there are cameras avail able. We can take a photography module as part of the course - I'm thinking about doing it because I love taking photos too. You can also do sub-editing, but I'm not as interested in that. The course is one year long and 87% of people who complete it are working in the industry within six months. I'm hoping to get a job on a local newspaper. · Amanda Doherty, 18, is doing an NVQ level 4 in newspaper journalism at the North West Institute of Further and Higher Education, Londonderry
